newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Court says Commission decisions binding on national courts.
newsitem.headline: Court says Commission decisions binding on national courts.

text.p: The European Court of Justice said on Thursday European Commission decisions declaring a vessel liable for Scrapping Fund contributions are final and binding on national courts, if not challenged within two months.

The two month statute of limitation under EC Treaty article 173 is supported by the need for legal certainty by preventing Community measures with a legal effect from being called into question indefinitely, the court said.

The Community legislation at issue in this case gives the Commission sole power to exempt specialized vessels from contributing to the Scrapping Fund. Instead of challenging the Commission directly, the plaintiff challenged Belgium's implementation of the Commission's decision that it was not exempt.
(Court translation into English. Original language of the case: Dutch)

"Structural improvements in inland waterway transport - Special contribution - Exclusion of specialized vessels - Commission decision rejecting an application for exemption - Decison not contested under article 173 of the Treaty - Validity of the decision then contested before the national court"
Reference from the Rechtbank van Koophandel, Antwerp, Belgium for a preliminary ruling between

on the interpretation of Council regulation (EEC) No 1101/89 of 27 April 1989 on structural improvements in inland waterway transport (OJ 1989 L 116, p. 25) and the validity of the Commission's decision of 6 May 1993 rejecting an application for exemption from the special contribution to the Scrapping Fund set up by article 8(1)(a) of that regulation

Where a Commission decision has been addressed to the owner of a vessel, finding that his vessel is not a specialized vessel within the meaning of article 8(3)(c) of Council regulation (EEC) No 1101/89 of 27 April 1989 on structural improvements in inland waterway transport, and the addressee has not brought an action under the fourth paragraph of article 173 of the EC Treaty against the decision within the time-limit prescribed, that decision is binding on the national court.
